# Cardiovascular Changes of Pregnancy

:::CICM
Explain the physiological changes during pregnancy and parturition
:::

:::ANZCA
Describe the physiological changes and their implications for anaesthesia that occur during pregnancy, labour and delivery, in particular the ~~respiratory~~, cardiovascular~~, haematological and gastrointestinal~~ changes.
:::

Pregnancy is a time of ↑↑ metabolic demand, which is reflected in the cardiovascular adaptations. These include:

* ↑ Intravascular volume\
Occurs via two mechanisms:
    * ↑ **Oestrogen** causes an **↑ plasma volume**
        * This ↓ capillary oncotic pressure, predisposing to oedema\
        This may be exacerbated by the gravid uterus compressing the IVC, especially near-term
    * ↑ **EPO** causes an **↑ red cell volume**
* ↑ Venous return\
Due to ↑ intravascular volume and MSFP.
  * The gravid uterus may compress the IVC and impair VR, hence pregnant women are positioned with a left lateral tilt to displace the uterus off the IVC
* ↑ VR causes an ↑ in CO, with both an ↑ in HR and SV, as well a ↓ in SVR
* ↓ SVR results in ↓ SBP, DBP and MAP, which occurs despite the ↑ in CO

## Magnitude of Changes by Trimester

+-------------------+-----------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Parameter         | Direction | 1^st^ Trimester | 2^nd^ Trimester | 3^rd^ Trimester |                                                                 | Notes                                                                           |
+===================+===========+=================+=================+=================+=================================================================+=================================================================================+
| **Plasma volume** | ↑         | 35%             | 45%             | 50%             | <img src="/resources/maternal-volume.svg" style="width: 15pc;"> | Peaks between 32-36^th^ week, ↓ slightly thereafter                             |
+-------------------+-----------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **Blood volume**  | ↑         | 5%              | 15%             | 20%             |                                                                 | ↑ Less than the ↑ in plasma volume, resulting in the fall in haematocrit to 33% |
+-------------------+-----------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **HR**            | ↑         | 15%             | 18%             | 25%             | <img src="/resources/maternal-hr.svg" style="width: 15pc;">     | ↑ Progressively throughout                                                      |
+-------------------+-----------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **SV**            | ↑         | 20%             | 25%             | 30%             | <img src="/resources/maternal-sv.svg" style="width: 15pc;">     | ↑ Progressively throughout                                                      |
+-------------------+-----------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **CO**            | ↑         | 20%             | 40%             | 45%             | <img src="/resources/maternal-co.svg" style="width: 15pc;">     | ↑ Throughout, and dramatically in labour                                        |
+-------------------+-----------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

## Changes During Labour

* Uterine contraction boluses ~300ml of blood into the maternal circulation\
Causes an ↑ in CO by up to 30% during the active phase and 45% during ejection.
    * Associated with corresponding increase in SBP and DBP by 10-20mmHg
* Post-partum CO is up to 80% of pre-labour values due to autotransfusion, and returns to normal within 2 weeks of delivery
